[All AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02 Questions]
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question:
A company notices that credentials that the company uses to connect to an
external software as a service (SaaS) vendor are stored in a configuration file
as plaintext.

The developer needs to secure the API credentials and enforce automatic
credentials rotation on a quarterly basis.

Which solution will meet these requirements MOST securely?
Chose_A: Use AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) to encrypt the configuration file. Decrypt the configuration file when users make API calls to the SaaS vendor. Enable rotation.
Chose_B: Retrieve temporary credentials from AWS Security Token Service (AWS STS) every 15 minutes. Use the temporary credentials when users make API calls to the SaaS vendor.
Chose_C: Store the credentials in AWS Secrets Manager and enable rotation. Configure the API to have Secrets Manager access.
Chose_D: Store the credentials in AWS Systems Manager Parameter Store and enable rotation. Retrieve the credentials when users make API calls to the SaaS vendor.
Explain: AWS Secrets Manager is the correct service for securely storing credentials and enabling automated rotation for external APIs.

Title:
Exam question from Amazon's AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question #: 271
Topic #: 1
[All AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02 Questions]
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question:
A company has an application that is hosted on Amazon EC2 instances. The
application stores objects in an Amazon S3 bucket and allows users to download
objects from the S3 bucket. A developer turns on S3 Block Public Access for the
S3 bucket. After this change, users report errors when they attempt to download
objects. The developer needs to implement a solution so that only users who are
signed in to the application can access objects in the S3 bucket.

Which combination of steps will meet these requirements in the MOST secure way?
(Choose two.)
Chose_A: Create an EC2 instance profile and role with an appropriate policy. Associate the role with the EC2 instances.
Chose_B: Create an IAM user with an appropriate policy. Store the access key ID and secret access key on the EC2 instances.
Chose_C: Modify the application to use the S3 GeneratePresignedUrl API call.
Chose_D: Modify the application to use the S3 GetObject API call and to return the object handle to the user.
Chose_E: E. Modify the application to delegate requests to the S3 bucket.
Explain: Use an EC2 instance role for secure S3 access and generate presigned URLs for users to download objects without exposing credentials.

Title:
Exam question from Amazon's AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question #: 272
Topic #: 1
[All AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02 Questions]
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question:
An Amazon Simple Queue Service (Amazon SQS) queue serves as an event source for
an AWS Lambda function. In the SQS queue, each item corresponds to a video file
that the Lambda function must convert to a smaller resolution. The Lambda
function is timing out on longer video files, but the Lambda function's timeout
is already configured to its maximum value.

What should a developer do to avoid the timeouts without additional code
changes?
Chose_A: Increase the memory configuration of the Lambda function.
Chose_B: Increase the visibility timeout on the SQS queue.
Chose_C: Increase the instance size of the host that runs the Lambda function.
Chose_D: Use multi-threading for the conversion.
Explain: Increasing Lambda memory also increases CPU, which speeds up compute‑intensive tasks like conversions.

Title:
Exam question from Amazon's AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question #: 273
Topic #: 1
[All AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02 Questions]
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question:
A company is building an application on AWS. The application's backend includes
an Amazon API Gateway REST API. The company's frontend application developers
cannot continue work until the backend API is ready for integration. The company
needs a solution that will allow the frontend application developers to continue
their work.

Which solution will meet these requirements in the MOST operationally efficient
way?
Chose_A: Configure mock integrations for API Gateway API methods.
Chose_B: Integrate a Lambda function with API Gateway and return a mocked response.
Chose_C: Add new API endpoints to the API Gateway stage and returns a mocked response.
Chose_D: Configure a proxy resource for API Gateway API methods.
Explain: Mock integrations are the correct way to test or simulate API Gateway responses without backend dependencies.

Title:
Exam question from Amazon's AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question #: 274
Topic #: 1
[All AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02 Questions]
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question:
A company is preparing to migrate an application to the company's first AWS
environment. Before this migration, a developer is creating a proof-of-concept
application to validate a model for building and deploying container-based
applications on AWS.

Which combination of steps should the developer take to deploy the containerized
proof-of-concept application with the LEAST operational effort? (Choose two.)
Chose_A: Package the application into a .zip file by using a command line tool. Upload the package to Amazon S3.
Chose_B: Package the application into a container image by using the Docker CLI. Upload the image to Amazon Elastic Container Registry (Amazon ECR).
Chose_C: Deploy the application to an Amazon EC2 instance by using AWS CodeDeploy.
Chose_D: Deploy the application to Amazon Elastic Kubernetes Service (Amazon EKS) on AWS Fargate.
Chose_E: E. Deploy the application to Amazon Elastic Container Service (Amazon ECS) on AWS Fargate.
Explain: Based on typical DVA-C02 patterns, packaging the application as a container image and deploying it to ECS on Fargate aligns with best practices.

Title:
Exam question from Amazon's AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question #: 275
Topic #: 1
[All AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02 Questions]
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question:
A developer supports an application that accesses data in an Amazon DynamoDB
table. One of the item attributes is expirationDate in the timestamp format. The
application uses this attribute to find items, archive them, and remove them
from the table based on the timestamp value.

The application will be decommissioned soon, and the developer must find another
way to implement this functionality. The developer needs a solution that will
require the least amount of code to write.

Which solution will meet these requirements?
Chose_A: Enable TTL on the expirationDate attribute in the table. Create a DynamoDB stream. Create an AWS Lambda function to process the deleted items. Create a DynamoDB trigger for the Lambda function.
Chose_B: Create two AWS Lambda functions: one to delete the items and one to process the items. Create a DynamoDB stream. Use the DeleteItem API operation to delete the items based on the expirationDate attribute. Use the GetRecords API operation to get the items from the DynamoDB stream and process them.
Chose_C: Create two AWS Lambda functions: one to delete the items and one to process the items. Create an Amazon EventBridge scheduled rule to invoke the Lambda functions. Use the DeleteItem API operation to delete the items based on the expirationDate attribute. Use the GetRecords API operation to get the items from the DynamoDB table and process them.
Chose_D: Enable TTL on the expirationDate attribute in the table. Specify an Amazon Simple Queue Service (Amazon SQS) dead-letter queue as the target to delete the items. Create an AWS Lambda function to process the items.
Explain: Enabling TTL with a DynamoDB stream and Lambda trigger is the correct pattern for processing expired items. TTL deletes items automatically and generates REMOVE events that Lambda can process from the stream.

Title:
Exam question from Amazon's AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question #: 276
Topic #: 1
[All AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02 Questions]
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question:
A developer needs to implement a custom machine learning (ML) library in an
application. The size of the library is 15 GB. The size of the library is
increasing. The application uses AWS Lambda functions. All the Lambda functions
must have access to the library.

Which solution will meet these requirements?
Chose_A: Save the library in Lambda layers. Attach the layers to all Lambda functions.
Chose_B: Save the library in Amazon S3. Download the library from Amazon S3 inside the Lambda function.
Chose_C: Save the library as a Lambda container image. Redeploy the Lambda functions with the new image.
Chose_D: Save the library in an Amazon Elastic File System (Amazon EFS) file system. Mount the EFS file system in all the Lambda functions.
Explain: Mounting a shared EFS file system allows all Lambda functions to use the same continuously updated library without redeployment. This fits scenarios where the library changes frequently.

Title:
Exam question from Amazon's AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question #: 277
Topic #: 1
[All AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02 Questions]
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question:
A developer is designing a serverless application for a game in which users
register and log in through a web browser. The application makes requests on
behalf of users to a set of AWS Lambda functions that run behind an Amazon API
Gateway HTTP API.

The developer needs to implement a solution to register and log in users on the
application's sign-in page. The solution must minimize operational overhead and
must minimize ongoing management of user identities.

Which solution will meet these requirements?
Chose_A: Create Amazon Cognito user pools for external social identity providers. Configure IAM roles for the identity pools.
Chose_B: Program the sign-in page to create users' IAM groups with the IAM roles attached to the groups.
Chose_C: Create an Amazon RDS for SQL Server DB instance to store the users and manage the permissions to the backend resources in AWS.
Chose_D: Configure the sign-in page to register and store the users and their passwords in an Amazon DynamoDB table with an attached IAM policy.
Explain: Amazon Cognito user pools and identity pools are the correct AWS-managed solution for handling authentication with external social identity providers and assigning IAM roles.

Title:
Exam question from Amazon's AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question #: 279
Topic #: 1
[All AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02 Questions]
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question:
A photo sharing application uses Amazon S3 to store image files. All user images
are manually audited for inappropriate content by a third-party company. The
audits are completed 1-24 hours after user upload and the results are written to
an Amazon DynamoDB table, which uses the S3 object key as a primary key. The
database items can be queried by using a REST API created by the third-party
company.

An application developer needs to implement an automated process to tag all S3
objects with the results of the content audit.

What should the developer do to meet these requirements in the MOST
operationally efficient way?
Chose_A: Create an AWS Lambda function to run in response to the s3:ObjectCreated event type. Write the S3 key to an Amazon Simple Queue Service (Amazon SQS) queue with a visibility timeout of 24 hours. Create and configure a second Lambda function to read items from the queue. Retrieve the results for each item from the DynamoDB table. Tag each S3 object accordingly.
Chose_B: Create an AWS Lambda function to run in response to the s3:ObjectCreated event type. Integrate the function into an AWS Step Functions standard workflow. Define an AWS Step Functions Wait state and set the value to 24 hours. Create and configure a second Lambda function to retrieve the audit results and tag the S3 objects accordingly after the Wait state is over.
Chose_C: Create an AWS Lambda function to load all untagged S3 objects. Retrieve the results for each item from the REST API and tag each S3 object accordingly. Create and configure an Amazon EventBridge rule to run at regular intervals. Set the Lambda function as a target for the EventBridge rule.
Chose_D: Launch an Amazon EC2 instance. Deploy a script to the EC2 instance to use the external database results to tag the S3 objects accordingly. Configure a crontab file to run the script at regular intervals.
Explain: Step Functions with a 24‑hour Wait state cleanly handles the required delay before retrieving audit results and tagging S3 objects, using event‑driven and serverless components.

Title:
Exam question from Amazon's AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question #: 280
Topic #: 1
[All AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02 Questions]
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question:
A company has built an AWS Lambda function to convert large image files into
output files that can be used in a third-party viewer application. The company
recently added a new module to the function to improve the output of the
generated files. However, the new module has increased the bundle size and has
increased the time that is needed to deploy changes to the function code.

How can a developer increase the speed of the Lambda function deployment?
Chose_A: Use AWS CodeDeploy to deploy the function code.
Chose_B: Use Lambda layers to package and load dependencies.
Chose_C: Increase the memory size of the function.
Chose_D: Use Amazon S3 to host the function dependencies.
Explain: Lambda layers are the correct method for packaging and loading external dependencies separately from the function code.

Title:
Exam question from Amazon's AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question #: 281
Topic #: 1
[All AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02 Questions]
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question:
A developer creates a static website for their department. The developer deploys
the static assets for the website to an Amazon S3 bucket and serves the assets
with Amazon CloudFront. The developer uses origin access control (OAC) on the
CloudFront distribution to access the S3 bucket.

The developer notices users can access the root URL and specific pages but
cannot access directories without specifying a file name. For example,
/products/index.html works, but /products/ returns an error. The developer needs
to enable accessing directories without specifying a file name without exposing
the S3 bucket publicly.

Which solution will meet these requirements?
Chose_A: Update the CloudFront distribution's settings to index.html as the default root object is set.
Chose_B: Update the Amazon S3 bucket settings and enable static website hosting. Specify index.html as the Index document. Update the S3 bucket policy to enable access. Update the CloudFront distribution's origin to use the S3 website endpoint.
Chose_C: Create a CloudFront function that examines the request URL and appends index.html when directories are being accessed. Add the function as a viewer request CloudFront function to the CloudFront distribution's behavior.
Chose_D: Create a custom error response on the CloudFront distribution with the HTTP error code set to the HTTP 404 Not Found response code and the response page path to /index.html. Set the HTTP response code to the HTTP 200 OK response code.
Explain: CloudFront’s default root object only works at the root, not in subdirectories. A CloudFront function can append index.html for directory-style requests, fixing the issue without requiring S3 static website hosting.

Title:
Exam question from Amazon's AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question #: 282
Topic #: 1
[All AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02 Questions]
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question:
A developer is testing a RESTful application that is deployed by using Amazon
API Gateway and AWS Lambda. When the developer tests the user login by using
credentials that are not valid, the developer receives an HTTP 405:
METHOD_NOT_ALLOWED error. The developer has verified that the test is sending
the correct request for the resource.

Which HTTP error should the application return in response to the request?
Chose_A: HTTP 401
Chose_B: HTTP 404
Chose_C: HTTP 503
Chose_D: HTTP 505
Explain: HTTP 401 indicates an authentication failure, which is the common correct response for AWS questions involving missing or invalid credentials.

Title:
Exam question from Amazon's AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question #: 283
Topic #: 1
[All AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02 Questions]
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question:
A developer must use multi-factor authentication (MFA) to access data in an
Amazon S3 bucket that is in another AWS account.

Which AWS Security Token Service (AWS STS) API operation should the developer
use with the MFA information to meet this requirement?
Chose_A: AssumeRoleWithWebIdentity
Chose_B: GetFederationToken
Chose_C: AssumeRoleWithSAML
Chose_D: AssumeRole
Explain: The question text is missing, so the correct answer cannot be determined from the provided information.

Title:
Exam question from Amazon's AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question #: 284
Topic #: 1
[All AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02 Questions]
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question:
A developer designed an application on an Amazon EC2 instance. The application
makes API requests to objects in an Amazon S3 bucket.

Which combination of steps will ensure that the application makes the API
requests in the MOST secure manner? (Choose two.)
Chose_A: Create an IAM user that has permissions to the S3 bucket. Add the user to an IAM group.
Chose_B: Create an IAM role that has permissions to the S3 bucket.
Chose_C: Add the IAM role to an instance profile. Attach the instance profile to the EC2 instance.
Chose_D: Create an IAM role that has permissions to the S3 bucket. Assign the role to an IAM group.
Chose_E: E. Store the credentials of the IAM user in the environment variables on the EC2 instance.
Explain: An EC2 instance should access S3 using an IAM role with S3 permissions attached through an instance profile, which is achieved with choices B and C.

Title:
Exam question from Amazon's AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question #: 285
Topic #: 1
[All AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02 Questions]
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question:
An AWS Lambda function requires read access to an Amazon S3 bucket and requires
read/write access to an Amazon DynamoDB table. The correct IAM policy already
exists.

What is the MOST secure way to grant the Lambda function access to the S3 bucket
and the DynamoDB table?
Chose_A: Attach the existing IAM policy to the Lambda function.
Chose_B: Create an IAM role for the Lambda function. Attach the existing IAM policy to the role. Attach the role to the Lambda function.
Chose_C: Create an IAM user with programmatic access. Attach the existing IAM policy to the user. Add the user access key ID and secret access key as environment variables in the Lambda function.
Chose_D: Add the AWS account root user access key ID and secret access key as encrypted environment variables in the Lambda function.
Explain: Lambda functions must assume an IAM execution role. You cannot attach an IAM policy directly to a Lambda function, and using IAM user keys is insecure. Therefore, creating an IAM role and attaching the policy is the correct solution.

Title:
Exam question from Amazon's AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question #: 286
Topic #: 1
[All AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02 Questions]
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question:
A developer is using AWS Step Functions to automate a workflow. The workflow
defines each step as an AWS Lambda function task. The developer notices that
runs of the Step Functions state machine fail in the GetResource task with
either an IllegalArgumentException error or a TooManyRequestsException error.

The developer wants the state machine to stop running when the state machine
encounters an IllegalArgumentException error. The state machine needs to retry
the GetResource task one additional time after 10 seconds if the state machine
encounters a TooManyRequestsException error. If the second attempt fails, the
developer wants the state machine to stop running.

How can the developer implement the Lambda retry functionality without adding
unnecessary complexity to the state machine?
Chose_A: Add a Delay task after the GetResource task. Add a catcher to the GetResource task. Configure the catcher with an error type of TooManyRequestsException. Configure the next step to be the Delay task. Configure the Delay task to wait for an interval of 10 seconds. Configure the next step to be the GetResource task.
Chose_B: Add a catcher to the GetResource task. Configure the catcher with an error type of TooManyRequestsException, an interval of 10 seconds, and a maximum attempts value of 1. Configure the next step to be the GetResource task.
Chose_C: Add a retrier to the GetResource task. Configure the retrier with an error type of TooManyRequestsException, an interval of 10 seconds, and a maximum attempts value of 1.
Chose_D: Duplicate the GetResource task. Rename the new GetResource task to TryAgain. Add a catcher to the original GetResource task. Configure the catcher with an error type of TooManyRequestsException. Configure the next step to be TryAgain.
Explain: Step Functions handles rate‑limit retries using a retrier on the task. A retrier is the correct way to automatically retry on TooManyRequestsException with a delay and attempt limit.

Title:
Exam question from Amazon's AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question #: 287
Topic #: 1
[All AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02 Questions]
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question:
A developer is creating a serverless application that uses an AWS Lambda
function. The developer will use AWS CloudFormation to deploy the application.
The application will write logs to Amazon CloudWatch Logs. The developer has
created a log group in a CloudFormation template for the application to use. The
developer needs to modify the CloudFormation template to make the name of the
log group available to the application at runtime.

Which solution will meet this requirement?
Chose_A: Use the AWS::Include transform in CloudFormation to provide the log group's name to the application.
Chose_B: Pass the log group's name to the application in the user data section of the CloudFormation template.
Chose_C: Use the CloudFormation template's Mappings section to specify the log group's name for the application.
Chose_D: Pass the log group's Amazon Resource Name (ARN) as an environment variable to the Lambda function.
Explain: Passing the log group’s ARN as an environment variable to the Lambda function is the correct and standard method for providing such configuration values.

Title:
Exam question from Amazon's AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question #: 288
Topic #: 1
[All AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02 Questions]
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question:
A developer is creating an Amazon DynamoDB table by using the AWS CLI. The
DynamoDB table must use server-side encryption with an AWS owned encryption key.

How should the developer create the DynamoDB table to meet these requirements?
Chose_A: Create an AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) customer managed key. Provide the key's Amazon Resource Name (ARN) in the KMSMasterKeyId parameter during creation of the DynamoDB table.
Chose_B: Create an AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) AWS managed key. Provide the key's Amazon Resource Name (ARN) in the KMSMasterKeyId parameter during creation of the DynamoDB table.
Chose_C: Create an AWS owned key. Provide the key's Amazon Resource Name (ARN) in the KMSMasterKeyId parameter during creation of the DynamoDB table.
Chose_D: Create the DynamoDB table with the default encryption options.
Explain: DynamoDB encrypts data at rest by default using an AWS owned key, which requires no configuration and is the simplest valid option unless the question states a requirement for a customer-managed key.

Title:
Exam question from Amazon's AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question #: 289
Topic #: 1
[All AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02 Questions]
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question:
A company has an application that runs across multiple AWS Regions. The
application is experiencing performance issues at irregular intervals. A
developer must use AWS X-Ray to implement distributed tracing for the
application to troubleshoot the root cause of the performance issues.

What should the developer do to meet this requirement?
Chose_A: Use the X-Ray console to add annotations for AWS services and user-defined services.
Chose_B: Use Region annotation that X-Ray adds automatically for AWS services. Add Region annotation for user-defined services.
Chose_C: Use the X-Ray daemon to add annotations for AWS services and user-defined services.
Chose_D: Use Region annotation that X-Ray adds automatically for user-defined services. Configure X-Ray to add Region annotation for AWS services.
Explain: X-Ray automatically adds Region annotations for AWS services, but user-defined services must add Region annotations manually.

Title:
Exam question from Amazon's AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question #: 290
Topic #: 1
[All AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02 Questions]
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question:
A company runs an application on AWS. The application uses an AWS Lambda
function that is configured with an Amazon Simple Queue Service (Amazon SQS)
queue called high priority queue as the event source. A developer is updating
the Lambda function with another SQS queue called low priority queue as the
event source. The Lambda function must always read up to 10 simultaneous
messages from the high priority queue before processing messages from low
priority queue. The Lambda function must be limited to 100 simultaneous
invocations.

Which solution will meet these requirements?
Chose_A: Set the event source mapping batch size to 10 for the high priority queue and to 90 for the low priority queue.
Chose_B: Set the delivery delay to 0 seconds for the high priority queue and to 10 seconds for the low priority queue.
Chose_C: Set the event source mapping maximum concurrency to 10 for the high priority queue and to 90 for the low priority queue.
Chose_D: Set the event source mapping batch window to 10 for the high priority queue and to 90 for the low priority queue.
Explain: Event source mapping maximum concurrency is the correct mechanism to prioritize SQS queues feeding a Lambda function. It controls how many concurrent Lambda invocations each queue can consume, allowing prioritization between queues.

Title:
Exam question from Amazon's AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question #: 291
Topic #: 1
[All AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02 Questions]
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question:
A data visualization company wants to strengthen the security of its core
applications. The applications are deployed on AWS across its development,
staging, pre-production, and production environments. The company needs to
encrypt all of its stored sensitive credentials. The sensitive credentials need
to be automatically rotated. A version of the sensitive credentials need to be
stored for each environment.

Which solution will meet these requirements in the MOST operationally efficient
way?
Chose_A: Configure AWS Secrets Manager versions to store different copies of the same credentials across multiple environments.
Chose_B: Create a new parameter version in AWS Systems Manager Parameter Store for each environment. Store the environment-specific credentials in the parameter version.
Chose_C: Configure the environment variables in the application code. Use different names for each environment type.
Chose_D: Configure AWS Secrets Manager to create a new secret for each environment type. Store the environment-specific credentials in the secret.
Explain: Each environment should have its own secret. AWS Secrets Manager best practice is to create separate secrets per environment rather than using versions or environment variables.

Title:
Exam question from Amazon's AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question #: 292
Topic #: 1
[All AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02 Questions]
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question:
A developer is investigating an issue in part of a company's application. In the
application, messages are sent to an Amazon Simple Queue Service (Amazon SQS)
queue. The AWS Lambda function polls messages from the SQS queue and sends email
messages by using Amazon Simple Email Service (Amazon SES). Users have been
receiving duplicate email messages during periods of high traffic.

Which reasons could explain the duplicate email messages? (Choose two.)
Chose_A: Standard SQS queues support at-least-once message delivery.
Chose_B: Standard SQS queues support exactly-once processing, so the duplicate email messages are because of user error.
Chose_C: Amazon SES has the DomainKeys Identified Mail (DKIM) authentication incorrectly configured.
Chose_D: The SQS queue's visibility timeout is lower than or the same as the Lambda function's timeout.
Chose_E: E. The Amazon SES bounce rate metric is too high.
Explain: Standard SQS delivers messages at least once and a visibility timeout shorter than the Lambda timeout can cause duplicate processing.

Title:
Exam question from Amazon's AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question #: 293
Topic #: 1
[All AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02 Questions]
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question:
A developer is deploying a company's application to Amazon EC2 instances. The
application generates gigabytes of data files each day. The files are rarely
accessed, but the files must be available to the application's users within
minutes of a request during the first year of storage. The company must retain
the files for 7 years.

How can the developer implement the application to meet these requirements MOST
cost-effectively?
Chose_A: Store the files in an Amazon S3 bucket. Use the S3 Glacier Instant Retrieval storage class. Create an S3 Lifecycle policy to transition the files to the S3 Glacier Deep Archive storage class after 1 year.
Chose_B: Store the files in an Amazon S3 bucket. Use the S3 Standard storage class. Create an S3 Lifecycle policy to transition the files to the S3 Glacier Flexible Retrieval storage class after 1 year.
Chose_C: Store the files on an Amazon Elastic Block Store (Amazon EBS) volume. Use Amazon Data Lifecycle Manager (Amazon DLM) to create snapshots of the EBS volumes and to store those snapshots in Amazon S3.
Chose_D: Store the files on an Amazon Elastic File System (Amazon EFS) mount. Configure EFS lifecycle management to transition the files to the EFS Standard- Infrequent Access (Standard-IA) storage class after 1 year.
Explain: Glacier Instant Retrieval is not suitable for files intended for inexpensive storage that will remain untouched for a year. S3 Standard transitioning to Glacier Flexible Retrieval is the appropriate low-cost archival pattern.

Title:
Exam question from Amazon's AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question #: 294
Topic #: 1
[All AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02 Questions]
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question:
A company's developer has deployed an application in AWS by using AWS
CloudFormation. The CloudFormation stack includes parameters in AWS Systems
Manager Parameter Store that the application uses as configuration settings. The
application can modify the parameter values.

When the developer updated the stack to create additional resources with tags,
the developer noted that the parameter values were reset and that the values
ignored the latest changes made by the application. The developer needs to
change the way the company deploys the CloudFormation stack. The developer also
needs to avoid resetting the parameter values outside the stack.

Which solution will meet these requirements with the LEAST development effort?
Chose_A: Modify the CloudFormation stack to set the deletion policy to Retain for the Parameter Store parameters.
Chose_B: Create an Amazon DynamoDB table as a resource in the CloudFormation stack to hold configuration data for the application. Migrate the parameters that the application is modifying from Parameter Store to the DynamoDB table.
Chose_C: Create an Amazon RDS DB instance as a resource in the CloudFormation stack. Create a table in the database for parameter configuration. Migrate the parameters that the application is modifying from Parameter Store to the configuration table.
Chose_D: Modify the CloudFormation stack policy to deny updates on Parameter Store parameters.
Explain: Setting a CloudFormation DeletionPolicy to Retain prevents CloudFormation from deleting SSM Parameter Store parameters that the application modifies independently, which is the intended solution.

Title:
Exam question from Amazon's AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question #: 295
Topic #: 1
[All AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02 Questions]
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question:
A company has a social media application that receives large amounts of traffic.
User posts and interactions are continuously updated in an Amazon RDS database.
The data changes frequently, and the data types can be complex. The application
must serve read requests with minimal latency.

The application's current architecture struggles to deliver these rapid data
updates efficiently. The company needs a solution to improve the application's
performance.

Which solution will meet these requirements?
Chose_A: Use Amazon DynamoDB Accelerator (DAX) in front of the RDS database to provide a caching layer for the high volume of rapidly changing data.
Chose_B: Set up Amazon S3 Transfer Acceleration on the RDS database to enhance the speed of data transfer from the databases to the application.
Chose_C: Add an Amazon CloudFront distribution in front of the RDS database to provide a caching layer for the high volume of rapidly changing data.
Chose_D: Create an Amazon ElastiCache for Redis cluster. Update the application code to use a write-through caching strategy and read the data from Redis.
Explain: ElastiCache for Redis with a write-through strategy is the correct caching solution for rapidly changing data stored in RDS. Other options do not apply to RDS or caching this type of workload.

Title:
Exam question from Amazon's AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question #: 296
Topic #: 1
[All AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02 Questions]
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question:
A developer created an AWS Lambda function that performs a series of operations
that involve multiple AWS services. The function's duration time is higher than
normal. To determine the cause of the issue, the developer must investigate
traffic between the services without changing the function code.

Which solution will meet these requirements?
Chose_A: Enable AWS X-Ray active tracing in the Lambda function. Review the logs in X-Ray.
Chose_B: Configure AWS CloudTrail. View the trail logs that are associated with the Lambda function.
Chose_C: Review the AWS Config logs in Amazon CloudWatch.
Chose_D: Review the Amazon CloudWatch logs that are associated with the Lambda function.
Explain: CloudWatch Logs are the default and primary location to review Lambda execution logs. X-Ray provides tracing but not full log output, so reviewing CloudWatch Logs is the correct choice.

Title:
Exam question from Amazon's AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question #: 297
Topic #: 1
[All AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02 Questions]
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question:
A company has on-premises data centers that run an image processing service. The
service consists of containerized applications that run on Kubernetes clusters.
All the applications have access to the same NFS share for files and data
storage.

The company is running out of NFS capacity in the data centers and needs to
migrate to AWS as soon as possible. The Kubernetes clusters must be highly
available on AWS.

Which combination of actions will meet these requirements? (Choose two.)
Chose_A: Transfer the information that is in the NFS share to an Amazon Elastic Block Store (Amazon EBS) volume. Upload the container images to Amazon Elastic Container Registry (Amazon ECR).
Chose_B: Transfer the information that is in the NFS share to an Amazon Elastic File System (Amazon EFS) volume. Upload the container images to Amazon Elastic Container Registry (Amazon ECR).
Chose_C: Create an Amazon Elastic Container Service (Amazon ECS) cluster to run the applications. Configure each node of the cluster to mount the Amazon Elastic Block Store (Amazon EBS) volume at the required path for the container images.
Chose_D: Create an Amazon Elastic Kubernetes Service (Amazon EKS) cluster to run the applications. Configure each node of the cluster to mount the Amazon Elastic Block Store (Amazon EBS) volume at the required path for the container images.
Chose_E: E. Create an Amazon Elastic Kubernetes Service (Amazon EKS) cluster to run the applications. Configure each node of the cluster to mount the Amazon Elastic File System (Amazon EFS) volume at the required path for the container images.
Explain: Container images should be stored in Amazon ECR, not on EFS. EFS is appropriate for migrating the NFS share data. EKS is unnecessary unless required by the question, so option E is incorrect. Option B correctly uses EFS for shared file storage and ECR for container images.

Title:
Exam question from Amazon's AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question #: 298
Topic #: 1
[All AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02 Questions]
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question:
A company has an analytics application that uses an AWS Lambda function to
process transaction data asynchronously. A developer notices that asynchronous
invocations of the Lambda function sometimes fail. When failed Lambda function
invocations occur, the developer wants to invoke a second Lambda function to
handle errors and log details.

Which solution will meet these requirements?
Chose_A: Configure a Lambda function destination with a failure condition. Specify Lambda function as the destination type. Specify the error-handling Lambda function's Amazon Resource Name (ARN) as the resource.
Chose_B: Enable AWS X-Ray active tracing on the initial Lambda function. Configure X-Ray to capture stack traces of the failed invocations. Invoke the error-handling Lambda function by including the stack traces in the event object.
Chose_C: Configure a Lambda function trigger with a failure condition. Specify Lambda function as the destination type. Specify the error-handling Lambda function's Amazon Resource Name (ARN) as the resource.
Chose_D: Create a status check alarm on the initial Lambda function. Configure the alarm to invoke the error-handling Lambda function when the alarm is initiated. Ensure that the alarm passes the stack trace in the event object.
Explain: Lambda destinations support failure conditions and can route failed invocations to another Lambda function, which matches the requirement.

Title:
Exam question from Amazon's AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question #: 299
Topic #: 1
[All AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02 Questions]
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question:
A company introduced a new feature that should be accessible to only a specific
group of premium customers. A developer needs the ability to turn the feature on
and off in response to performance and feedback. The developer needs a solution
to validate and deploy these configurations quickly without causing any
disruptions.

What should the developer do to meet these requirements?
Chose_A: Use AWS AppConfig to manage the feature configuration and to validate and deploy changes. Use feature flags to turn the feature on and off.
Chose_B: Use AWS Secrets Manager to securely manage and validate the feature configurations. Enable lifecycle rules to turn the feature on and off.
Chose_C: Use AWS Config to manage the feature configuration and validation. Set up AWS Config rules to turn the feature on and off based on predefined conditions.
Chose_D: Use AWS Systems Manager Parameter Store to store and validate the configuration settings for the feature. Enable lifecycle rules to turn the feature on and off.
Explain: AWS AppConfig is the correct service for feature flags, configuration management, and safe deployments with validation.

Title:
Exam question from Amazon's AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question #: 300
Topic #: 1
[All AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02 Questions]
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question:
A developer needs approval from a product owner before the developer can deploy
code for an application to production. The developer uses AWS CodePipeline to
deploy the application. The developer configures an Amazon Simple Notification
Service (Amazon SNS) topic to send notifications to the product owner.

Which solution is the MOST operationally efficient way for the developer to
receive approval from the product owner?
Chose_A: Add a new stage to CodePipeline before the production deployment. Add a manual approval action to the new stage. Add a new notification rule in the pipeline settings. Specify manual approval as the event that initiates the notification. Specify the SNS topic's Amazon Resource Name (ARN) to notify the product owner.
Chose_B: Develop an AWS Step Functions state machine that sends a notification to the product owner and accepts an approval. Add a new stage to CodePipeline before the production deployment. Add the state machine as a Step Functions action to the new stage.
Chose_C: Add a manual approval action to the existing production deployment stage in CodePipeline. Specify the SNS topic's Amazon Resource Name (ARN) while configuring the new manual approval action.
Chose_D: Edit the settings in CodePipeline. Create a new notification rule. Specify manual approval as the event that initiates the notification. Create a new notification target. Specify the SNS topic to notify the product owner. Save the notification rule.
Explain: A manual approval action in CodePipeline natively supports specifying an SNS topic for notifications. Adding an extra stage and notification rule is unnecessary. Option C is the correct and simplest solution.

Title:
Exam question from Amazon's AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question #: 301
Topic #: 1
[All AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02 Questions]
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question:
A developer is building a serverless application on AWS for a workflow that
processes high volumes of data. In the workflow, an AWS Step Functions state
machine invokes several AWS Lambda functions.

One of the Lambda functions occasionally fails because of timeout errors during
periods of high demand. The developer must ensure that the workflow
automatically retries the failed function invocation if a timeout error occurs.

Which solution will meet this requirement?
Chose_A: Add a Retry field in the Step Functions state machine definition. Configure the state machine with the maximum number of retry attempts and the timeout error type to retry on.
Chose_B: Add a Timeout field in the Step Functions state machine definition. Configure the state machine with the maximum number of retry attempts.
Chose_C: Add a Fail state to the Step Functions state machine definition. Configure the state machine with the maximum number of retry attempts.
Chose_D: Update the Step Functions state machine to pass the invocation request to an Amazon Simple Notification Service (Amazon SNS) topic. Subscribe a Lambda function to the SNS topic. Configure the Lambda function with the maximum number of retry attempts for a timeout error type.
Explain: Step Functions supports built‑in retries using the Retry field, allowing configuration of retry attempts and error types such as timeouts.

Title:
Exam question from Amazon's AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question #: 303
Topic #: 1
[All AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02 Questions]
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question:
A company runs an application on AWS. The application consists of a static
website that is hosted on Amazon S3. The application includes Amazon API Gateway
APIs that invoke AWS Lambda functions. During a period of high traffic on the
application, application users reported that the application was slow at
irregular intervals. There were no failed requests.

A developer needs to find the slow executions across all the Lambda functions.

Which solution will meet these requirements?
Chose_A: Perform a query across all the Lambda function log groups by using Amazon CloudWatch Logs Insights. Filter on type of report and sort descending by Lambda function execution duration.
Chose_B: Enable AWS CloudTrail Insights on the account where the Lambda functions are running. After CloudTrail Insights has finished processing, review CloudTrail Insights to find the anomalous functions.
Chose_C: Enable AWS X-Ray for all the Lambda functions. Configure an X-Ray insight on a new group that includes all the Lambda functions. After the X-Ray insight has finished processing, review the X-Ray logs.
Chose_D: Set up AWS Glue to crawl through the logs in Amazon CloudWatch Logs for the Lambda functions. Configure an AWS Glue job to transform the logs into a structured format and to output the logs into Amazon S3. Use the Amazon CloudWatch dashboard to visualize the slowest functions based on the duration.
Explain: CloudWatch Logs Insights can directly query Lambda REPORT log entries to identify the slowest functions without requiring code changes. X-Ray must be instrumented in each function and is not needed for simple duration analysis.

Title:
Exam question from Amazon's AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question #: 304
Topic #: 1
[All AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02 Questions]
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question:
A company is building a serverless application on AWS. The application uses
Amazon API Gateway and AWS Lambda. The company wants to deploy the application
to its development, test, and production environments.

Which solution will meet these requirements with the LEAST development effort?
Chose_A: Use API Gateway stage variables and create Lambda aliases to reference environment-specific resources.
Chose_B: Use Amazon Elastic Container Service (Amazon ECS) to deploy the application to the environments.
Chose_C: Duplicate the code for each environment. Deploy the code to a separate API Gateway stage.
Chose_D: Use AWS Elastic Beanstalk to deploy the application to the environments.
Explain: API Gateway stage variables with Lambda aliases are the correct way to manage environment‑specific configurations without duplicating code.

Title:
Exam question from Amazon's AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question #: 305
Topic #: 1
[All AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02 Questions]
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question:
A developer uses AWS CloudFormation to deploy an Amazon API Gateway API and an
AWS Step Functions state machine. The state machine must reference the API
Gateway API after the CloudFormation template is deployed. The developer needs a
solution that uses the state machine to reference the API Gateway endpoint.

Which solution will meet these requirements MOST cost-effectively?
Chose_A: Configure the CloudFormation template to reference the API endpoint in the DefinitionSubstitutions property for the AWS::StepFunctions::StateMachine resource.
Chose_B: Configure the CloudFormation template to store the API endpoint in an environment variable for the AWS::StepFunctions::StateMachine resource. Configure the state machine to reference the environment variable.
Chose_C: Configure the CloudFormation template to store the API endpoint in a standard AWS::SecretsManager::Secret resource. Configure the state machine to reference the resource.
Chose_D: Configure the CloudFormation template to store the API endpoint in a standard AWS::AppConfig::ConfigurationProfile resource. Configure the state machine to reference the resource.
Explain: DefinitionSubstitutions is the correct way for CloudFormation to pass dynamic values such as API endpoints into an AWS Step Functions state machine definition.

Title:
Exam question from Amazon's AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question #: 308
Topic #: 1
[All AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02 Questions]
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question:
A company needs to deploy all its cloud resources by using AWS CloudFormation
templates. A developer must create an Amazon Simple Notification Service (Amazon
SNS) automatic notification to help enforce this rule. The developer creates an
SNS topic and subscribes the email address of the company's security team to the
SNS topic.

The security team must receive a notification immediately if an IAM role is
created without the use of CloudFormation.

Which solution will meet this requirement?
Chose_A: Create an AWS Lambda function to filter events from CloudTrail if a role was created without CloudFormation. Configure the Lambda function to publish to the SNS topic. Create an Amazon EventBridge schedule to invoke the Lambda function every 15 minutes.
Chose_B: Create an AWS Fargate task in Amazon Elastic Container Service (Amazon ECS) to filter events from CloudTrail if a role was created without CloudFormation. Configure the Fargate task to publish to the SNS topic. Create an Amazon EventBridge schedule to run the Fargate task every 15 minutes.
Chose_C: Launch an Amazon EC2 instance that includes a script to filter events from CloudTrail if a role was created without CloudFormation. Configure the script to publish to the SNS topic. Create a cron job to run the script on tile EC2 instance every 15 minutes.
Chose_D: Create an Amazon EventBridge rule to filter events from CloudTrail if a role was created without CloudFormation. Specify the SNS topic as the target of the EventBridge rule.
Explain: EventBridge can directly filter CloudTrail CreateRole events and detect those not created by CloudFormation, then send them to SNS without polling or additional compute.

Title:
Exam question from Amazon's AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question #: 318
Topic #: 1
[All AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02 Questions]
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question:
A company is releasing a new feature. Users can request early access to the new
feature by using an application form. The company expects a surge of requests
when the application form becomes available. Each request will be stored as an
item in an Amazon DynamoDB table.

Each item will contain the user's username, the submission date, and a
validation status of UNVALIDATED. VALID, or NOT VALID. Each item also will
contain the user's rating of the process on a scale of 1 to 5.

Each user can submit one request. For the DynamoDB table, the developer must
choose a partition key that will give the workload well-distributed records
across partitions.

Which DynamoDB attribute will meet these requirements?
Chose_A: Username
Chose_B: Submission date
Chose_C: Validation status
Chose_D: Rating of the process on a scale of 1 to 5
Explain: Without the full question, the most reasonable assumption is that 'Username' is the correct choice, matching the majority vote.

Title:
Exam question from Amazon's AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question #: 319
Topic #: 1
[All AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02 Questions]
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question:
A developer is creating a publicly accessible enterprise website consisting of
only static assets. The developer is hosting the website in Amazon S3 and
serving the website to users through an Amazon CloudFront distribution. The
users of this application must not be able to access the application content
directly from an S3 bucket. All content must be served through the Amazon
CloudFront distribution.

Which solution will meet these requirements?
Chose_A: Create a new origin access control (OAC) in CloudFront. Configure the CloudFront distribution's origin to use the new OAC. Update the S3 bucket policy to allow CloudFront OAC with read and write access to access Amazon S3 as the origin.
Chose_B: Update the S3 bucket settings. Enable the block all public access setting in Amazon S3. Configure the CloudFront distribution's with Amazon S3 as the origin. Update the S3 bucket policy to allow CloudFront write access.
Chose_C: Update the S3 bucket's static website settings. Enable static website hosting and specifying index and error documents. Update the CloudFront origin to use the S3 bucket's website endpoint.
Chose_D: Update the CloudFront distribution's origin to send a custom header. Update the S3 bucket policy with a condition by using the aws:RequestTag/tag-key key. Configure the tag-key as the custom header name, and the value being matched is the header's value.
Explain: Origin Access Control (OAC) is the correct modern method for restricting S3 access to CloudFront. The S3 bucket must trust the OAC, not public access or website endpoints.

Title:
Exam question from Amazon's AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question #: 328
Topic #: 1
[All AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02 Questions]
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question:
A developer is working on an ecommerce platform that communicates with several
third-party payment processing APIs. The third-party payment services do not
provide a test environment.

The developer needs to validate the ecommerce platform's integration with the
third-party payment processing APIs. The developer must test the API integration
code without invoking the third-party payment processing APIs.

Which solution will meet these requirements?
Chose_A: Set up an Amazon API Gateway REST API with a gateway response configured for status code 200. Add response templates that contain sample responses captured from the real third-party API.
Chose_B: Set up an AWS AppSync GraphQL API with a data source configured for each third-party API. Specify an integration type of Mock. Configure integration responses by using sample responses captured from the real third-party API.
Chose_C: Create an AWS Lambda function for each third-party API. Embed responses captured from the real third-party API. Configure Amazon Route 53 Resolver with an inbound endpoint for each Lambda function's Amazon Resource Name (ARN).
Chose_D: Set up an Amazon API Gateway REST API for each third-party API. Specify an integration request type of Mock. Configure integration responses by using sample responses captured from the real third-party API.
Explain: API Gateway Mock integrations are the correct way to simulate third‑party API responses using predefined sample payloads.

Title:
Exam question from Amazon's AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question #: 329
Topic #: 1
[All AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02 Questions]
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question:
A developer is storing many objects in a single Amazon S3 bucket. The developer
needs to optimize the S3 bucket for high request rates.

How should the developer store the objects to meet this requirement?
Chose_A: Store the objects by using S3 Intelligent-Tiering.
Chose_B: Store the objects at the root of the S3 bucket.
Chose_C: Store the objects by using object key names distributed across multiple prefixes.
Chose_D: Store each object with an object tag named "prefix" that contains a unique value.
Explain: Distributing object key names across multiple prefixes improves S3 request performance and scalability.

Title:
Exam question from Amazon's AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question #: 330
Topic #: 1
[All AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02 Questions]
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question:
A company deploys a new application to AWS. The company is streaming application
logs to Amazon CloudWatch Logs. The company's development team must receive
notification by email when the word "ERROR" appears in any log lines. A
developer sets up an Amazon Simple Notification Service (Amazon SNS) topic and
subscribes the development team to the topic.

What should the developer do next to meet the requirements?
Chose_A: Select the appropriate log group. Create a CloudWatch metric filter with "ERROR" as the search term. Create an alarm on this metric that notifies the SNS topic when the metric is 1 or higher.
Chose_B: In CloudWatch Logs Insights, select the appropriate log group. Create a metric query to search for the term "ERROR" in the logs. Create an alarm on this metric that notifies the SNS topic when the metric is 1 or higher.
Chose_C: Select the appropriate log group. Create an SNS subscription filter with "ERROR" as the filter pattern. Select the SNS topic as the destination.
Chose_D: Create a CloudWatch alarm that includes "ERROR" as a filter pattern, a log group dimension that defines the appropriate log group, and a destination that notifies the SNS topic.
Explain: To trigger an alarm based on specific text in CloudWatch Logs, you must create a metric filter on the log group and then build an alarm on that metric. Option A is the correct AWS-native workflow.

Title:
Exam question from Amazon's AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question #: 331
Topic #: 1
[All AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02 Questions]
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question:
A company uses Amazon Simple Queue Service (Amazon SQS) to decouple its
microservices architecture. Some messages in an SQS queue contain sensitive
information. A developer must implement a solution that encrypts all the data at
rest.

Which solution will meet this requirement?
Chose_A: Enable server-side encryption for the SQS queue by using an SQS managed encryption key (SSE-SQS).
Chose_B: Use the aws:SecureTransport condition in the queue policy to ensure that only HTTPS (TLS) is used for all requests to the SQS queue.
Chose_C: Use AWS Certificate Manager (ACM) to generate an SSL/TLS certificate. Reference the certificate when messages are sent to the queue.
Chose_D: Set a message attribute in the SQS SendMessage request for messages that are sent to the queue. Set the Name to ENCRYPT. Set the Value to TRUE.
Explain: SSE-SQS (A) provides encryption at rest only. To enforce encryption in transit, the queue policy must require HTTPS by using the aws:SecureTransport condition.

Title:
Exam question from Amazon's AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question #: 332
Topic #: 1
[All AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02 Questions]
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question:
A company recently deployed a new serverless user portal. Users have reported
that part of the portal is slow. The initial analysis found a single Amazon API
Gateway endpoint that is responsible for the performance issues. The endpoint
integrates with an AWS Lambda function. However, the Lambda function interacts
with other APIs and AWS services.

How can a developer find the source of the increased response time by using
operational best practices?
Chose_A: Update the Lambda function by adding logging statements with high-precision timestamps before and after each external request. Deploy the updated Lambda function. After accumulating enough usage data, examine the Amazon CloudWatch logs for the Lambda function to determine the likely sources for the increased response time.
Chose_B: Instrument the Lambda function with the AWS X-Ray SDK. Add HTTP and HTTPS interceptors and SDK client handlers. Deploy the updated Lambda function. Turn on X-Ray tracing. After accumulating enough usage data, use the X-Ray service map to examine the average response times to determine the likely sources.
Chose_C: Review the Lambda function's Amazon CloudWatch metrics by using the metrics explorer. Apply anomaly detection to the Duration metric and the Throttles metric. Review the anomalies to determine the likely sources.
Chose_D: Use Amazon CloudWatch Synthetics to create a new canary. Turn on AWS X-Ray tracing on the canary. Configure the canary to scan the user portal. After accumulating enough usage data, use the CloudWatch Synthetics canary dashboard to view the metrics from the canary.
Explain: X-Ray provides end-to-end tracing of Lambda invocations and external calls, making it the best tool to identify latency sources.

Title:
Exam question from Amazon's AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question #: 334
Topic #: 1
[All AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02 Questions]
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question:
A company's application has an AWS Lambda function that processes messages from
IoT devices. The company wants to monitor the Lambda function to ensure that the
Lambda function is meeting its required service level agreement (SLA).

A developer must implement a solution to determine the application's throughput
in near real time. The throughput must be based on the number of messages that
the Lambda function receives and processes in a given time period. The Lambda
function performs initialization and post-processing steps that must not factor
into the throughput measurement.

What should the developer do to meet these requirements?
Chose_A: Use the Lambda function's ConcurrentExecutions metric in Amazon CloudWatch to measure the throughput.
Chose_B: Modify the application to log the calculated throughput to Amazon CloudWatch Logs. Use Amazon EventBridge to invoke a separate Lambda function to process the logs on a schedule.
Chose_C: Modify the application to publish custom Amazon CloudWatch metrics when the Lambda function receives and processes each message. Use the metrics to calculate the throughput.
Chose_D: Use the Lambda function's Invocations metric and Duration metric to calculate the throughput in Amazon CloudWatch.
Explain: Publishing custom CloudWatch metrics for each received and processed message is the correct and precise way to measure throughput for a Lambda-based message‑processing application.

Title:
Exam question from Amazon's AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question #: 335
Topic #: 1
[All AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02 Questions]
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question:
A developer is using an AWS CodePipeline pipeline to provide continuous
integration and continuous delivery (CI/CD) support for a Java application. The
developer needs to update the pipeline to support the introduction of a new
application dependency .jar file. The pipeline must start a build when a new
version of the .jar file becomes available.

Which solution will meet these requirements?
Chose_A: Create an Amazon S3 bucket to store the dependency .jar file. Publish the dependency .jar file to the S3 bucket. Use an Amazon Simple Notification Service (Amazon SNS) notification to start a CodePipeline pipeline build.
Chose_B: Create an Amazon Elastic Container Registry (Amazon ECR) private repository. Publish the dependency .jar file to the repository. Use an ECR source action to start a CodePipeline pipeline build.
Chose_C: Create an Amazon Elastic Container Registry (Amazon ECR) private repository. Publish the dependency .jar file to the repository. Use an Amazon Simple Notification Service (Amazon SNS) notification to start a CodePipeline pipeline build.
Chose_D: Create an AWS CodeArtifact repository. Publish the dependency .jar file to the repository. Use an Amazon EventBridge rule to start a CodePipeline pipeline build.
Explain: CodeArtifact is the correct service for storing and versioning dependency JAR files, and EventBridge can trigger CodePipeline when new artifacts are published.

Title:
Exam question from Amazon's AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question #: 338
Topic #: 1
[All AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02 Questions]
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question:
A company is using AWS CloudFormation templates to deploy AWS resources. The
company needs to update one of its AWS CloudFormation stacks.

What can the company do to find out how the changes will impact the resources
that are running?
Chose_A: Investigate the change sets.
Chose_B: Investigate the stack policies.
Chose_C: Investigate the Metadata section.
Chose_D: Investigate the Resources section.
Explain: Without the full question, the most reasonable and commonly correct choice in CloudFormation troubleshooting scenarios involving changes is to inspect the change sets.

Title:
Exam question from Amazon's AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question #: 333
Topic #: 1
[All AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02 Questions]
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question:
A developer is building an event-driven application by using AWS Lambda and
Amazon EventBridge. The Lambda function needs to push events to an EventBridge
event bus. The developer uses an SDK to run the PutEvents EventBridge action and
specifies no credentials in the code. After deploying the Lambda function, the
developer notices that the function is failing and there are
AccessDeniedException errors in the logs.

How should the developer resolve this issue?
Chose_A: Configure a VPC peering connection between the Lambda function and EventBridge.
Chose_B: Modify their AWS credentials to include permissions for the PutEvents EventBridge action.
Chose_C: Modify the Lambda function execution role to include permissions for the PutEvents EventBridge action.
Chose_D: Add a resource-based policy to the Lambda function to include permissions for the PutEvents EventBridge action.
Explain: A Lambda function needs IAM permissions in its execution role to call PutEvents on EventBridge. Adding a resource-based policy to the Lambda function is not how EventBridge authorization works.

Title:
Exam question from Amazon's AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question #: 336
Topic #: 1
[All AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02 Questions]
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question:
A company with multiple branch locations has an analytics and reporting
application. Each branch office pushes a sales report to a shared Amazon S3
bucket at a predefined time each day. The company has developed an AWS Lambda
function that analyzes the reports from all branch offices in a single pass. The
Lambda function stores the results in a database.

The company needs to start the analysis once each day at a specific time.

Which solution will meet these requirements MOST cost-effectively?
Chose_A: Configure an S3 event notification to invoke the Lambda function when a branch office uploads a sales report.
Chose_B: Create an AWS Step Functions state machine that invokes the Lambda function once each day at the predefined time.
Chose_C: Configure the Lambda function to run continuously and to begin analysis only at the predefined time each day.
Chose_D: Create an Amazon EventBridge scheduled rule that invokes the Lambda function once each day at the predefined time.
Explain: A daily scheduled invocation of a Lambda function should be done using an EventBridge scheduled rule.

Title:
Exam question from Amazon's AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question #: 337
Topic #: 1
[All AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02 Questions]
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question:
A developer has an application that asynchronously invokes an AWS Lambda
function. The developer wants to store messages that resulted in failed
invocations of the Lambda function so that the application can retry the call
later.

What should the developer do to accomplish this goal with the LEAST operational
overhead?
Chose_A: Set up Amazon CloudWatch Logs log groups to filter and store the messages in an Amazon S3 bucket. Import the messages in Lambda. Run the Lambda function again.
Chose_B: Configure Amazon EventBridge to send the messages to Amazon Simple Notification Service (Amazon SNS) to initiate the Lambda function again.
Chose_C: Implement a dead-letter queue for discarded messages. Set the dead-letter queue as an event source for the Lambda function.
Chose_D: Send Amazon EventBridge events to an Amazon Simple Queue Service (Amazon SQS) queue. Configure the Lambda function to pull messages from the SQS queue. Run the Lambda function again.
Explain: A dead-letter queue is the correct mechanism for capturing discarded Lambda event messages and reprocessing them.

Title:
Exam question from Amazon's AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question #: 339
Topic #: 1
[All AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02 Questions]
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question:
A company stores all personally identifiable information (PII) in an Amazon
DynamoDB table named PII in Account A. Developers are working on an application
that is running on Amazon EC2 instances in Account B. The application in Account
B requires access to the PII table.

An administrator in Account A creates an IAM role named AccessPII that has
permission to access the PII table. The administrator also creates a trust
policy that specifies Account B as a principal that can assume the role.

Which combination of steps should the developers take in Account B to allow
their application to access the PII table? (Choose two.)
Chose_A: Allow the EC2 IAM role the permission to assume the AccessPII role.
Chose_B: Allow the EC2 IAM role the permission to access the PII table.
Chose_C: Include the AWS API in the application code logic to obtain temporary credentials from the EC2 IAM role to access the PII table.
Chose_D: Include the AssumeRole API operation in the application code logic to obtain temporary credentials to access the PII table.
Chose_E: E. Include the GetSessionToken API operation in the application code logic to obtain temporary credentials to access the PII table.
Explain: The EC2 instance role must be allowed to assume the AccessPII role, and the application must call AssumeRole to obtain temporary credentials.

Title:
Exam question from Amazon's AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question #: 340
Topic #: 1
[All AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02 Questions]
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question:
A gaming website gives users the ability to trade game items with each other on
the platform. The platform requires both users' records to be updated and
persisted in one transaction. If any update fails, the transaction must roll
back.

Which AWS solutions can provide the transactional capability that is required
for this feature? (Choose two.)
Chose_A: Amazon DynamoDB with operations made with the ConsistentRead parameter set to true
Chose_B: Amazon ElastiCache for Memcached with operations made within a transaction block
Chose_C: Amazon DynamoDB with reads and writes made by using Transact* operations
Chose_D: Amazon Aurora MySQL with operations made within a transaction block
Chose_E: E. Amazon Athena with operations made within a transaction block
Explain: DynamoDB supports ACID transactions via Transact* APIs, and Aurora MySQL supports transactions through standard SQL transaction blocks.

Title:
Exam question from Amazon's AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question #: 341
Topic #: 1
[All AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02 Questions]
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question:
A developer is deploying an application in the AWS Cloud by using AWS
CloudFormation. The application will connect to an existing Amazon RDS database.
The hostname of the RDS database is stored in AWS Systems Manager Parameter
Store as a plaintext value. The developer needs to incorporate the database
hostname into the CloudFormation template to initialize the application when the
stack is created.

How should the developer reference the parameter that contains the database
hostname?
Chose_A: Use the ssm dynamic reference.
Chose_B: Use the Ref intrinsic function.
Chose_C: Use the Fn::ImportValue intrinsic function.
Chose_D: Use the ssm-secure dynamic reference.
Explain: The standard ssm dynamic reference is used for retrieving non-secure Parameter Store values directly in CloudFormation templates. The ssm-secure reference is only needed for SecureString parameters.

Title:
Exam question from Amazon's AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question #: 342
Topic #: 1
[All AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02 Questions]
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question:
A company uses an AWS Lambda function to call a third-party service. The
third-party service has a limit of requests each minute. If the number of
requests exceeds the limit, the third-party service returns rate-limiting
errors.

A developer needs to configure the Lambda function to avoid receiving rate
limiting errors from the third-party service.

Which solution will meet these requirements?
Chose_A: Set the reserved concurrency on the Lambda function to match the number of concurrent requests that the third-party service allows.
Chose_B: Decrease the memory that is allocated to the Lambda function.
Chose_C: Set the provisioned concurrency on the Lambda function to match the number of concurrent requests that the third-party service allows.
Chose_D: Increase the timeout value that is specified on the Lambda function.
Explain: Reserved concurrency limits the maximum concurrent executions of a Lambda function, preventing it from overwhelming a third-party service with more requests than allowed.

Title:
Exam question from Amazon's AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question #: 343
Topic #: 1
[All AWS Certified Developer - Associate DVA-C02 Questions]
[/exams/amazon/aws-certified-developer-associate-dva-c02/]
Question:
A developer is building a new containerized application by using AWS Copilot.
The developer uses the AWS Copilot command line interface (CLI) to deploy the
application during development. The developer committed the application code to
a new AWS CodeCommit repository. The developer must create an automated
deployment process before releasing the new application to production.

What should the developer do to meet these requirements in the MOST
operationally efficient way?
Chose_A: Create a buildspec file that invokes the AWS Copilot CLI commands to build and deploy the application. Use the AWS Copilot CLI to create an AWS CodePipeline that uses the CodeCommit repository in the source stage and AWS CodeBuild in the build stage.
Chose_B: Use the AWS Serverless Application Model (AWS SAM) CLI to bootstrap and initialize an AWS CodePipeline configuration. Use the CodeCommit repository as the source. Invoke the AWS Copilot CLI to build and deploy the application.
Chose_C: Use the AWS Copilot CLI to define the AWS Copilot pipeline and to deploy the AWS CodePipeline. Select CodeCommit as the source for the AWS CodePipeline.
